description:
Doc fixes:

--Adding in some more cross-references and format updates specifically to analysis_modules, developing docs, examining docs.

--Updating instructions on how to upgrade to the new version of yt; including a note on rebuilding yt in the ``help`` document, and a note on how to switch between 2.x and 3.x versions in the install document.

--Reincluded the pastebin information

--Update the available fields description a bit more

--Added cross-references all over the place.

--Made it so "yt version" reveals if the repo has been modified with a "+" on the end (just like hg does).

--Addressing all of @ngoldbaum 's comments.
title: Docs updates

content.raw: Not true. `yt` is the dev branch. `stable` is the stable branch.
content.html: Not true. yt is the dev branch. stable is the stable branch.

content.raw: `develop`, not install.
content.html: develop, not install.

content.raw: or `build_ext -i`.
content.html: or build_ext -i.

content.raw: This is out of date - many more frontends have answer tests now.  Not sure whether it's worth updating - I don't think anyone has tried setting up answer tests anywhere but on jenkins in a long time.
content.html: This is out of date - many more frontends have answer tests now. Not sure whether it's worth updating - I don't think anyone has tried setting up answer tests anywhere but on jenkins in a long time.

content.raw: Why did this section get deleted?
content.html: Why did this section get deleted?

content.raw: Maybe note that `--all` is only useful if you built using the install script.
content.html: Maybe note that --all is only useful if you built using the install script.

content.raw: I was simply changing the formatting, I was not updating because I don't know the testing framework.  If someone else wants to update this, then please feel free to do so.
content.html: I was simply changing the formatting, I was not updating because I don't know the testing framework. If someone else wants to update this, then please feel free to do so.

content.raw: There is already a description of the pastebin almost verbatim to this in the command line docs.  The second section with --paste no longer works.
content.html: There is already a description of the pastebin almost verbatim to this in the command line docs. The second section with --paste no longer works.

content.raw: I'd say delete `Error Reporting with the Pastebin` but leave this section.
content.html: I'd say delete Error Reporting with the Pastebin but leave this section.

content.raw: I'm not sure I agree.  This section is about debugging, and the pastebin really doesn't have much to do with debugging.  And the description in the command line docs describes the whole functionality of the pastebin.
content.html: I'm not sure I agree. This section is about debugging, and the pastebin really doesn't have much to do with debugging. And the description in the command line docs describes the whole functionality of the pastebin.

content.raw: Again, disagree - the pastebin is super helpful for debugging.  It's useful to have this description here and all of this information is correct and up to date.
content.html: Again, disagree - the pastebin is super helpful for debugging. It's useful to have this description here and all of this information is correct and up to date.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: I think I have to agree with @ngoldbaum.  This section is relevant to debugging as it's how one can easily share tracebacks with others.  Personally, I'm ok with having a little redundancy because it's all about where you go looking in the docs when you need something.  I don't think someone would think to look in the command line section if they were having trouble debugging.
content.html: I think I have to agree with Nathan Goldbaum. This section is relevant to debugging as it's how one can easily share tracebacks with others. Personally, I'm ok with having a little redundancy because it's all about where you go looking in the docs when you need something. I don't think someone would think to look in the command line section if they were having trouble debugging.

content.html: Typo

content.html: Add a line where hg clone is invoked.

content.html: Besides the two nits below LGTM

content.html: If someone else could look this over and then hit the merge button if they approve, that would be very much appreciated.
